data.text: The Priority Continuum Onyx: Is It Good for Touring?

# Has anyone had experience and/or opinions on touring with the Priority Continuum Onyx? It's a Chinese made commuter bike with low maintenance requirements and some very nice advanced features at a great price point.
PRIORITY CONTINUUM ONYX - Priority Bicycles

Style, simplicity, and safety unite at an unmatched value for all-season commuters and sport touring riders. The Continuum Onyx offers...

prioritybicycles.com
Is it made in China? I thought it was made in the USA. Internal hub that won't get you up a lot of hills. Best for flat urban commuting.
data.author: Chris Burruto

data.text: Priority is based in NYC. But of course they outsource manufacturing.
data.author: Greg Gautreaux

data.text: frame is made in China. It's painted and assembled in the U.S. is how I understand things with their process. I literally got my first Priority bike today (Classic Plus) and it's a high quality bike considering it's their entry level bike. My son had the Start 20 and that thing was a tank. I sold it last weekend and shipped it to a buyer in Vermont. Pretty much everything we touch from Walmart grade garbage to higher price points are made in China, or Taiwan, Vietnam, Indonesia, etc.
data.author: Joelle Brodeur

data.text: Joelle Brodeur You may have misunderstood my comment as disparaging Chinese bikes. Not the case—I have 2 priority bikes myself. Their QC could be better on wheel build quality, but they’ve been super helpful for me at every turn
data.author: Greg Gautreaux

data.text: my apologies if I misunderstood. Lots of people have issue with the outsourcing practice. On a related note, I had my wheels trued yesterday along with a brake adjustment and overall inspection. I've heard in passing about their wheels before on models like the 600, Apollo and Current. I don't think I've seen that mentioned amongst Classic Plus owners.
data.author: Joelle Brodeur

data.text: There’s a Priority Bikes group. Generally they get good reviews (P.S. nearly every bike is manufactured in China). I love the Belt Drive idea. Have one of their eBikes and a city bike. Their customer service is very responsive and helpful
data.author: Greg Gautreaux

data.text: okay. I’m not here to argue whatever you’re getting at. Most bikes are made in China. Just a fact. And Priority bikes are fine.

data.text: How about the gear ratio on this commuter model. Is it good for general touring?
data.author: Tim Webster

data.text: shoot an email to Priority; they’ll respond within a day. Just let them know what you’re looking for and any concerns. I’m not sure about the low gear on the Enviolo with a load. Much more expertise in the Priority Riders & Friends group.
data.author: Greg Gautreaux

data.text: we had a couple guys from Sweden passing through here on the Oregon coast they had started in Anchorage AK . and planned to fly home from Miami Florida they were on 5 speed hub Commuter bikes...
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text:
Btw, looked more at that bike. Looks like it has an Enviolo Trekking hub, which is 380% range. If the low gear is not low enough for you, the easier thing to do would be to get a smaller front/bigger rear ring. Priority could more than likely help with recommendations there, if not outright sell you what you need. https://enviolo.com/products/ Depending on budget, consider the Apollo (more for gravel) or 600 (another commuter, but has a pinion drive with 600% range)
Discover enviolo manual and automatic hub products for bicycles - enviolo
enviolo.com
data.author: Greg Gautreaux

data.text: thanks for those tips
data.author: Tim Webster

data.text: I have heard of people touring on a Priority 600, though i think it has a wider gearing range than the hub gearing on the continuum onyx. The automatic lights on both models are really cool for both commuters and bike tourists.
data.author: Ryan Jeambey

data.text: yep, the 600 has a pinion drive.
data.author: Greg Gautreaux

data.text: I replied and bookface auto declined my response for some reason?
data.author: Ryan Jeambey

data.text: might be the d-word. Some auto-censoring algorithms are quite prudish.
data.author: David Rowe

data.text: I just checked Allie Denham's touring bicycle buying guide and the Priority 600X looks to have a 15"-90" gearing range out of the box. Which should be pretty good for hauling gear and climbing hills, I think. He doesn't have the Priority model the OP was asking about, though.
data.author: David Rowe

data.text: Only swap out the enviolo for like a rohloff or a Shimano alfine 11 speed like i did since there were no rohloff in stock atm
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: and there will be a proportional price increase for a new wheel build & hub to add to the price; definitely have more range, but not a ton. 409% to 380%. And Rohloff is excellent at 500%, and also $$$
data.author: Greg Gautreaux

data.text: the diffrence you will notice since the enviolo shift automaticlly for you which i personally did not like when hill climbing etc and the alfine runs on oil like the rohloff the difference in 380% and 409% in the field is alottt paperwork doesnt say anything about that i ride one on my get to town bike and bar drinking the enviolo when under heavy load it tends to skip which is a no go hill climbing with a load doesnt work well either the alfine on the other hand the lowest gear i have yet to see when climbing did go from a 22t in the rear to a 28t the enviolo is hard to maintain aswell during touring
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: the alfine 11 is also sold as a complete wheel build up already only need to slap a tyre on and maybe tubes and go
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: yeah, I have to guess it's in the $400+ USD range as a full wheel?
data.author: Greg Gautreaux

data.text: depending on the wheelset its built with i got mine for 350 on sale with extra thick double butted spokes which normally cost more but now since on sale and same price and normal wheel i went with it sometimes you find one for about 300 euros
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: Personally, I'd be cautious about a belt drive, especially if you are planning long trips. Either way, have a chat to your LBC about replacing the belt if/when it snaps. I notice it has a Gates belt drive (which is good, assuming it's not a knock-off), and they are supposed to have a very long life, but replacement can be expensive and not straightforward (LBC wouldn't keep this kind of thing in stock). There is an inherent attraction to belt drives, but a chain would be much more straightforward - and allow for modification if needed (e.g., if you need to change the sprocket or chainring to get a more suitable gear range).
data.author: David Rowe

data.text: I assure you they're Gates belts. And a spare is easy to carry. I'd say replacement is trivial, but the Enviolo *will* make it more challenging with 2 cables to remove first. Replacement belts are $40 right on Priority's site.
data.author: Greg Gautreaux

data.text: I recently spoke with a tourer whose Gates belt replacement also required a new sprocket (albeit he had gone a long distance on the same belt). Admittedly, he didn't carry a spare belt (which was probably a bit shortsighted), but he had to wait several weeks for a new sprocket (same size, not different). Regardless, the OP needs to be very sure the gear range is suitable for what he wants, as he'd need to buy a new belt and sprocket if it's not.
data.author: David Rowe

data.text: yeah, Gates are a different beastie, & the sprocket/ring wears faster than the belt. 100% concur on being sure about the gear range. And belt tension is absolutely more challenging than a chain with rear cogs & derailleur. If you need help, in the middle of nowhere, chain-related parts are totally going to be easier to get hold of currently.
data.author: Greg Gautreaux

data.text: Belt tension is not hard on my Priority Apollo. Belt doesn't stretch like a chain over time, but if you get a flat on the back you do need to check the tension after repairing and remounting. Just adjust with a hex wrench -- there's a simple way to do that at the back hub and an online app for checking tension via vibration sound.
data.author: Pete Ramsey

data.text: yeah, i've tried that app and gotten wildly different readings on my Current. It's not very useful IMO. The directions for the app are pretty useless too.
data.author: Greg Gautreaux

data.text: a belt is physically easier to replace that a chain...yes you need to replace it with a same size belt, but otherwise it is a 5 minute job.
data.author: Mark Stratmann

data.text: Slightly off-topic, but check out Ryan Van Duzer's YouTube channel. He bikepacks with a Priority 600x and has multiple videos about the bike including one where the belt snapped and in the video he and the company go through the how, why, what happened etc.
data.author: Karl Maersch

data.text: Not off-topic at all - I knew I had seen this before, but had forgotten it was Ryan Duzer. Didn't he make some mistake, like running the belt too slack? I remember he was giving it mea culpa in the video.
data.author: David Rowe

data.text: I think his belt came off one time and he forced it back on and they concluded that that was the reason the belt failed. Just between us kids, it sort of felt like the explanation video was a little contrived for Priority to save face because a system that had been celebrated in like every.single.episode as super reliable actually failed, but that's me and my grassy knoll meter probably sees the boogie man in places where he doesn't exist sometimes.
data.author: Karl Maersch

data.text: You've got my OCD going now. I'll have to go back and re-watch it.
data.author: David Rowe

data.text: yep, he went through a boatload of mud, and rolled the belt off instead of removing properly; conference call with I forget who, said he should've just tightened the belt tension temporarily in those conditions to help better shed the muck
data.author: Greg Gautreaux

data.text:
Cyclingabout is a great YouTube channel and website with tons of information. Here's a great place to read up on belt drives - https://www.cyclingabout.com/carbon-belt-drive-everything-you-ever-need-to-know/

data.text: just got my Priority today. Frame has a sticker. The frame itself is not stamped with the Made in China designation. It's a well crafted bike. There's nothing cheap about it and the components.
data.author: Joelle Brodeur

data.text: A touchy subject in teh Middle Kingdom!
data.author: Rene Ordman

data.text: Not personally that specific bike but seems a bit pricey, and, what’s “low maintenance requirements”? All bikes require cleaning, lubing, and periodic tuning, wheel truing, etc. Belt drive may not need to be lubes, but Any pneumatic tires risk punctures, and replacing a rear tube on this bike looks quite a bit more involved than a conventional set up. Plus finding replacement parts and how expensive are they to replace?Wonder how much that rear hub weighs? I have to say, especially for that price, there are better choices
data.author: Clinton Mason

data.text: i ride belt drive myself taking the wheel out is just as easy as with a normal chain and casette only 1 step extra needed that is to take out the shifter cable which can be done with your fingers no tools needed then undo wheel nuts and take out the wheel
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: plus the parts are decently available and they last a very very long time so if you know how many miles you ride for and how new/worn the parts are you will know way before they need replacement and can order spares accordingly or order up front keep them at home or at a friend who can send them over for you
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: what do you consider as better choices in the $1000 to $2000 range?
data.author: Tim Webster

data.text: , Well I’m just thinking of what’s widely available around the world. When you ask people about specific prices, you’re going to get different opinions. I’d like to think you get what you pay for.
data.author: Clinton Mason

data.text: , I see what you’re saying, I guess this is really where you become your best doctor. How remote are you going,..etc,etc.
data.author: Clinton Mason

data.text: No experience with that model, but I ride a belt drive bike and love it...I just assembled my kids Priority bike and it is a nice little 16" wheel kids bike...impressed for what it is and they shipped it a few hours after I ordered it.
data.author: Mark Stratmann

data.text: I had a secondhand, 3 year old Priority Start 20 for my son. He quickly outgrew that bike (growth spurt), however he loved that bike to death. The frame was a bit banged up (kids), but nothing else was wrong with the bike. Drivetrain was dead perfect and excellent build quality. I just sold that bike 2 weeks ago and shipped it to Vermont. After selling that bike, I took delivery of my backordered Classic Plus (pictured). Identical drivetrain to the kids bikes. These are well made bikes for the money. For the commuter/recreation/kids line of their bikes are very affordable for gates equipped bikes.
data.author: Joelle Brodeur

data.text: If you’re looking for Chinese brands, look no further than Darkrock. By far the best rip off of Surly I have ever ridden.
data.author: Sajid Mo

data.text: Or you can just buy a real Surly.
data.author: Andrew Cattani
